subject: Implement Expand
commitMessage:
Implement Expand

Section 7.3 of the Redfish specification lays out a feature called
"expand" that allows users to expand portions of the Redfish tree
automatically on the server side.  This commit implements them to the
specification.

To accomplish this, a new class, MultiAsyncResp is created, that allows
RAII objects to handle lifetime properly.  When an expand query is
generated, a MultiAsyncResp object is instantiated, which allows "new"
requests to attach themselves to the multi object, and keep the request
alive until they all complete.  This also allows requests to be created,
while requests are in flight, which is required for queries above
depth=1.

Negatives:
Similar to the previous $only commit, this requires that all nodes
redfish nodes now capture App by reference.  This is common, but does
interfere with some of our other patterns, and attempts to improve the
syntactic sugar for this proved unworkable.

This commit only adds the above to service root and Computer systems, in
hopes that we find a better syntax before this merges.

Left to future patches in series:
Merging the error json structures in responses.

The Redfish spec isn't very clear on how errors propagate for expanded
queries, and in a conforming we shouldn't ever hit them, but
nonetheless, I suspect the behavior we have is sub-optimal (attaching an
error node to every place in the tree that had an issue) and we should
attempt to do better in the future.

Tested (on previous patch):

curl --insecure --user root:0penBmc https://localhost:18080/redfish/v1\?\$expand\=.\(\$levels\=255\)
Returns the full tree

Setting $levels=1 query returns only a depth of 1 tree being returned.

Unit tests passing

Signed-off-by: Ed Tanous <edtanous@google.com>
Change-Id: I874aabfaa9df5dbf832a80ec62ae65369284791d

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 7cf436c913a109c0d3ebf7e696970966500bc6b6
This can be in a common lib I assume.
I don't think so.  This class is pretty specific to expand, but is there another place that you think this would be used?
Please close this if you think this is resolved, or reply if you want to discuss this more.
Ack
can this return std::optional<Query>?

In this patchset, it wouldn't be used;  We tend to try to avoid doing unused things in code.  I'm assuming you're wanting to use that for an optimized sensor expand, but I don't think returning just Query would get you what you need.  Lets talk through this more on discord or something.  If we want to return std::optional<query> from another overload of this function, we could, but I don't think that will change this function much.

Marking as done, please reopen if you think that this patchset needs to change significantly.
why struct not class given that we have private members.

There's no design guideline on this, which is why I went with struct, but sure, I can do class, it doesn't make any difference.

Done.
Consider another name, final is a C++ keyword.
Good point.  Changed to finalResIn
Can we unit test this function? Seems unit-testable.
to unit test it would require an abstraction for app, which, I'm not sure we have a pattern for mocking out at this point.
Ack
some headers are missing, e.g., json, stream

Good catch.  I think those were the only two that were missing, right?

Pretty sure this is Done
Why not let the compiler choose its underlying integral type?

Because there are a number of cases where this is passed/copied by value, so keeping the Query struct small is agood, and the compiler without the hint will pick int, which is wasteful.  There is a compiler option that can influence this as well, but I didn't want to apply that to all of bmcweb.

Ack. I thought compiler is smart enough to choose the least integral that's large enough.

Checked the C++ standard, it says this is "implementation-defined". Won't bother check GCC or Clang. Setting to uint8_t LGTM.

> Ack. I thought compiler is smart enough to choose the least integral that's large enough.

It picks the one that is "fastest" ie the word-aligned one (int).

> 
> Checked the C++ standard, it says this is "implementation-defined". Won't bother check GCC or Clang. Setting to uint8_t LGTM.

I double checked the Spec, these names are misleading to me.

In the spec,

1. * expands all hyperlinks
2. . expands all hyperlinks not in any links property
3. ~ expands only hyperlinks that are links property

So, all Expand types are for hyperlinkes, the difference is whether to expand hyperlinks in "links property" or not.

I suggest changing these names to

{
  None,
  AllHyperlinks,
  HyperlinksNotLinksProperty,
  LinksProperty
}

> I double checked the Spec, these names are misleading to me.
> 
> In the spec,
> 
> 1. * expands all hyperlinks
> 2. . expands all hyperlinks not in any links property
> 3. ~ expands only hyperlinks that are links property
> 
> So, all Expand types are for hyperlinkes, the difference is whether to expand hyperlinks in "links property" or not.
> 
> I suggest changing these names to
> 
> {
>   None,
>   AllHyperlinks,
>   HyperlinksNotLinksProperty,
>   LinksProperty
> }

In a previous patchset it was basically that naming convention.  Happy to go back to

None,
NotLinks
Links,
All

if that works for you?  I'd rather not include the name "Property" because technically in Redfish, they aren't properties, they're NavigationReferences.  And I'd rather not include the word Hyperlinks, because of your previous comment that they're all hyperlinks.
I made the above change.  Done.  Please recomment if the above wasn't what you were thinking.
Ack. Naming LGTM now.
shouldn't this be both? Please also consider my above comments to rename expand types.
Yep, Good catch.  Will fix.
Done

‘*’ means both.
'~' means link property.
Will fix.
Done
should it only update `query.expandLevel` when it is confirmed that the format is correct like when `value == ")"` at the very end.

Why?  If the call site for this function ignores the return code, that feels like a programming error at the call site.  If you really want it moved, I'm happy to add an intermediate variable, but it adds extra complexity,  Arguably, this is a minor extension on std::from_chars, which makes no promises about the value of the output not being filled in if an error is returned.

I was thinking of maybe it is a good idea to dump-proof the code, but maybe that's not worth the extra complexity. but yeah, you are right that using the value without checking the error is programming errors.

I am fine with the it is without the change.
we discard `query.expandLevel` if this function returns false.
Done

I was testing this. "redfish/v1/Chassis/fake_chassis?$expand=." gave me wrong results. 

Period shall expand sources like sensors under this chassis but not links property (e.g., ComputerSystems, ManagedBy). Testing result shows that here we don't expand anything.

tilde shall expand only links property. Testing results shows it expands both.
Tracking for this error is covered on line 42.  I'm closing this comment, and will track resolving it on that comment chain, but agreed, this is an issue.
nit: flip the logic to save horizontal space?
ACK.  This was done this way so that it could be a switch statment at one poitn if we ever had to support more types, but as written, you're right, omiting this scope would be better.
Done
#include <nlohmann/json.hpp>?
Done
Can add a trivial test case to cover parseParameters
Done.  I had forgotten we talked about that, thanks for the reminder.
We shall also add a max level here given Expand is enabled
Is maxLevel required when we have no max level?  I thought it was optional, and this patchset doesn't impose a max level, so I intentionally omitted it.

It is required. See my latest patch. In the standard, the max level shall be between 1 and 6.

Please search MaxLevels
https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/ServiceRoot.v1_13_0.json
Please mark as resolved if this looks good.
Where do you see that it's required?  Technically 6 is incorrect, although considering that the spec I think only goes 6 layers at the deepest, might be ok?
"This property shall contain the maximum $levels option value in the $expand query parameter.  Shall be included only if $levels is true."
ACK
Done
missing the config header here
Ack

now we have to check the actual value of the level, right?

We limit it to 6

Yes, but not in this patch;  I would like to avoid any limits at the moment so people can test (there are systems with OEM schemas deeper than 6 that I'm aware of).  Thats why I initially omitted the maxDepth property, but considering it's required, and this is behind an "insecure, don't use in production" flag, we should be ok here.
Done
This function took me a while to read and understand. Is there anyway to help people understand what it is doing? Reading the test is one, what else can we do?
I'm open to changes.  What would you suggest to make this function easier to grok?
More comments, e.g., explaining what |jsonResponse| and the json pointer |p| mean and their relationship
Added more comments.
nit: miss this; but prefer to put output parameters to the end;

Not something that I think we have a cpp core guidelines rule for, and not something I would probably enforce, but sure, seems reasonable.

Done
All comments look addressed, and have a couple different maintainers +1s.  As always, happy to discuss, but I think this is good enough to go under the experimental flag.
